content:
The statement is poorly worded.
Please make it clear that the distance of output character is measured from the second character.
Although that can be inferred from the examples, the statement should be as clear as possible.
Also I am not a native speaker but I am pretty sure that "on the same distance" is not proper English.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear, no problems.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This would be a fun Clash of Code

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: little fun

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Don't really like the idea.

There is a mistake in your solution code: when you 'circle', you subtract 25 (output=output-90+65 = output - 25), but that should be 26 (output=output-90+64). [Credits to the sharp eye of 5DN1L who saw inconsistency in cases.]

Suggest to rephrase the goal statement to something like this: 'You are given two uppercase letters. Output the letter that is on the same distance from the second letter, as the distance between the first and second letter.'
Also, please make sure that test- and validator cases are well matched. For example, test 1 is the easy case, so validator 1 (test 2 in your naming) should be an equally easy case (eg CD->E). The circling around is more difficult, so preferably should come in a later test case with a similar validator case.

Subjet is not 100% clear I think. I first understood that the answer character should be in the middle of the two input characters (AE => C). You should should be more explicit about this.

Maybe also use "character" instead of "letter" ?
Ok, thanks.
Ok, thanks.
Please give justification
Thank You for your opinion.
Thank You for your opinion.
Thank You for your opinion.

Ok so the justification if you are not already convinced this is a bad problem. The solution for this problem is just a line, more than that you accept circularity such that the solution is just arificially made harder, maybe some people don't know from head the ascii codes and it would take them a lot more just because you want the alphabet to be ciclic. Sorry but this problem is too artificial, not interesting and might be a lot of trouble implementing for begginers.

Most everybody here to get experience in programming, so task must give learn.
If we will make tasks like guess 2+2 ? or some of such kind - what will you have study???
First time I also didn't understand  tasks, but now this problem almost dissappeared.

Ok so you don't get the toxicity of this problem, here are two variants, you give nice problem with a short solution fun to solve, or you just give a toxic task and ask for something, your problem is in the second category.
Will see by voting. you made yours. Anyway thank you for your time.

Thank you for your comment, jddingemanse :D

@Oliverri : I suggest you to adopt the wording suggested by jddingemanse, and add the following:

The distance between two letters is defined as the second letter's position in the alphabet, relative to the first letter's position, on a wrap-around basis. Wrap-around means that we will go back to {{A}} after reaching {{Z}}.

For example,
• For {{AZ}}, the distance is 25.
• For {{YA}}, the distance is 2.

Thanks.

Other comments

Title
* Please change "character" to "letters".

Input section
* Please mention the variable name [[MESSAGE]].

Constraints section
* Please change "[[characters]]" to "each letter in [[MESSAGE]]".

Thanks.

I think such explaining will make puzzle too easy, may be better leave some incomprehensibility to give posibility for player to roll brain for minimum. 
What do you think about it?
It's merely unclear instructions. The suggested rewording does not really give away any hints on how to write the code.
Ok.
Also, you can actually enable Reverse mode for this clash to give possibility for players to roll their brains :wink:
That seems not bad idea :-) Thanks.

Constraints section
* Please change "[[letters]]" to "each letter in [[MESSAGE]]". This is suggested so that the variable names are consistent, and also each letter is considered separately (i.e. subject to the same constraint).

Thanks.

To me, a character can be alphabetic and non-alphabetic (e.g. digits and special characters), while a letter must be alphabetic. So I prefer "letter" to "character".

Goal section is still very unclear, and I can't understand the logic of the cases.

I try to interpret the tests as follows:

Test 1 seems ok.
A to B: distance is 1, B to C: distance is 1

Test 2
X to Z: distance is 2, Z to C: distance is 3?

Test 3
A to Z: distance is 25, Z to Z: distance is 0?

Test 4
G to T: distance is 13, T to H: distance is 14?

Test 5
K to W: distance is 12, W to J: distance is 13?

Test 6
B to Y: distance is 23, Y to W: distance is 24?

Test 7 seems ok.
R to U: distance is 3, U to X: distance is 3

Test 8 seems ok.
D to E: distance is 1, E to F: distance is 1

Thanks.

That is weird indeed - I think there is a mistake in the solution code. In the case that you need to go around (e.g. A->Z->...), the solution code resolves this with if higher than 90, subtract (90-65) from that value. This should be (90-64) (i.e. the line output=output-90+65 should be output=output-90+64). The current code moves only 25 back, when it should be 26.
Corrected, thanks for such deep studying
